reviewText:
As far as RTS's go, I dont like them. Too many of them do their systems too incorrectly, or just dont plain make any logical sense, or reason. Dawn of War (all the expansion packs, consider this a recommendation for Dawn of War + all of the expansions), does some critical things right, which makes it stand out from the crowd.

First, it actually focuses on strategy for the most part. Instead of spamming 1000 tanks at your enemy (im looking at you Ruse), you actually have chose a limited number of units to bring into battle. Meaning, every man, tank, and resourse is valuble, and losing any of the above can cost you the battle. This tension, and balencing on the brink of death keeps tension high, as players must constantly have to outdo their opponent on a mental capacity, not necessarily on a quanitative capacity. This conbined with some rather unique in game mechanics, such as morale, means interesting strategies can arise, when those similar would fall flat in other RTS's.

And secondly, the game is able to keep a consistent feeling, tone, and atmosphere. Even for a strategy game, this is important, nothing takes you out of a game more than an interface, so even immersing the mission select screen in 40k does its job. Everything is plastered with 40k jargon and logic, a dark universe of war, death, and betrayal. As well, the game itself feels fitting, with you not taking resources, just getting requisition points to send in more troops, as you are successful in conquest, just as an example of many different things the game does right.

The game is fitting, and is able to keep a consistent feel to gameplay and atmosphere. For this, I must heartily recommend Dawn of War to RTS fans, you will not be let down.

I wont discuss the mechanics or the diversity.  Look to the other comments for that ♥♥♥♥.  I am simply giving a story and some true as Khorne is bloodthirsty observations.  As I begin remember that in the future, there is only war.  One must choose his battlecry well.  For the Greater Good.

One of the best RTS games out there.  Nothing quite beats some of the moments the game brings on.  The following is a part of a game I did (in skirmish) against the ai with 6 bots vs just my ai partner and I:

As I looked at my minimap, I realized my buddy's base was quickly getting overwhelmed.  His outer defenses were obliterated not a few minutes ago, and yet the enemy was closing in around his HQ.  He was building guardsmen as quickly as he could but the onslaught of orks, chaos space marines, and necrons were too much.  His commander made a valiant last stand, but it was in vain...I was then alone.

I scrutinized my defenses and realized I was lacking.  I quickly built many turrets as my first line of defense with some space marines around a pass that funneled the enemy forces down and caused them to lose some of the advantage of numbers.  My second line were multiple heavy tanks with melee infantry further behind the pass.  The purpose of this line was a bullet magnet while my base spit out as many units as I could for a heroic last stand.  The third line was whoever else was left at the time the other two lines fell.  As I checked my units upgrades and made sure they had all they could have, then I saw a red tide on the minimap.  I realized the Emperor would be seeing us soon in the next life.

As the enemy forces through themselves at the turrets, I couldn't help but realize the corpses of the dead.  The game has an option that leaves almost all the corpses on the field, and I recommend to turn it on to the max as it adds satisfaction to the price your men are paying.  The turrets and supporting infantry could only hold on for so long.  Before the line was breached I was in about a 7:1 kd ratio.  After the line was broken, it became a 1:1.  I zoomed in close for a final look at these men, and I grinned for I knew we would all be joining him soon.  The second line held for about half the time.  The third and final line consisted of my commander and everyone else that had not died.  I waited until the enemy was within weapon's range, then I lit them up with artillery, orbital strikes, and the last two flyers I had.  Then, my men charged.  They went down valiantly with many enemies dead in the process.

I knew there was no chance for victory from the very beginning, but I watched as my commander made his final defiant yell, I was sad there was never a chance.  I was fighting for time, and I got a lot of time.  We fought until the final drop of blood was spilt, until the final breath was exhaled, until the fat ♥♥♥ ho sang, until the bitter end.

These are the moments that define gaming, not the scripted ones that everyone encounters, but the ones that are player-made.  The game modes where the goal is to kill the enemy commander, and you are completely surrounded on all sides and you make a final charge to kill him to gain victory, and you see your numbers fall from 30 to 23 to 14 to 6 until all you have left is two guardsmen (they die sooooooo easily) and a tank that has a third of its health left and you win.  You win against all the odds, and you smirk at the trail of the men that died for victory.  I cannot tell you of all the awesomeness that is this game.  Go get it.

reviewText:
Multiplayer now Gamespy free! (Steamworks)
(Single player review) Every species and faction from the previous Dawn of War main game + Expansions, with two new factions and a campaign that is almost a copy of Dark Crusade. Which is a good thing, considering how much fun Dark Crusade was with the added burden of choices and a persistent battlefield.
The two new factions possess enough uniqueness to make them viable alternatives to the series mainstays. I've personally come to prefer the Sisters of Battle over Chaos due to the Sister's faith mechanic, where faith serves as a resource for various units to use for healing and attack bonuses in addition to whatever normal abilities the units possess. The Sisters also have a much greater reliance on melee and flame-based weapons compared to many of the other factions. I personally have no interest in the Dark Eldar, but the new faction's soul-harvesting mechanic dosen't sound like anything the other factions have.
My only real complaint agianst Soulstorm is that the additions to the single player campain seem poorly planed. Firstly, there's very little in the way of additions from Dark Crusade, but this isn't automatically a bad thing. What is troublesome, however, is that the main change, a move from a single planet battlefield to multiple, dosen't allow for zoom or any perspective changes. This means you may encounter difficulty seeing areas of the main battle map, where you view your territories and the territories of your enemies, at higher resolutions. Some tactical planning may be hampered by this, but this is not a large complaint.
If you have any interest in 40k, or if you are tired of Dark Crusade, or even if you just want to see a mostly-female (not all female, for some reason) human faction (I can't tell when it comes to the Eldar, but I guess they're female, too), pick up this game.  You don't need the other Dawn of War 1 games unless you really like space marine (Dawn of War base game) or Imperial Guard (Winter Assualt) plotlines. You will need the other games to unlock the other factions in multiplayer (already have all factions unlocked for any and all single player aspects).

reviewText:
I've got quite an unusual opinion about Soulstorm compared to Dark Crusade. Most people think Dark Crusade was more balanced and was a overall better release, but I think that Soulstorm was far better designed (in terms of balance and replayability), though greatly flawed on release. In Dark Crusade, there was extremely heavy bias towards Tau and Necrons (being a Tau player myself), and unforgiving brutality to Imperial Guard players due to being extremely underpowered, though it was nice for the planet to stay persistant with what happened on it.(I.e, you defeat an ork encampment and establish a massive Eldar base, if that is then attacked, you will be returned to your base EXACTLY as you built it to retaliate).

In Soulstorm, everything (faction-wise) is perfected. It had horrific problems running on release, it's annoying that your base is basically cast aside at the end of a mission, meaning that if you are attacked you have to build your base from scratch (unless you invest funds) and the addition of flying units is a bit odd, but most (if not all) Tau units have been nerfed, as they should be, and all necron units were also nerfed. Subsequently, all Imperial Guard units were also buffed, providing an equal battleground for all of the (now) 9 factions in Soulstorm. Apart from Dark Eldar, they're like the new Imperial Guard.

But who wants to play as space emos?

If you're more into the lore and fluff of the universe, (and cringe when you see a space marine get cut down by a single guardsman), and would rather play something thats a little more faithful to the factions, I'd recommend DoW II and its expansions. It sacrifices strategic scale battles and faction choice in favour of tactical scale battles and realism (in terms of the 40k universe).

reviewText:
This is definitely one of the best RTS games out there, have been playing it for 8 years now (not all the time) but I have not found any RTS that matches this. here are a few reasons why.

1. The huge range of units and races:
Ok so most RTS games will default to 3 or 4 factions, this one however (as long as you have all the other expansions and core game) gives you up to 9 playable races. and its not like their all similar either, each race is completely unique and different.

2. no rule restrictions:
So some RTS games I have recently had a look at will limit rules, for instance you cannot set your own teams, map position etc. This has a wide range of rules you can change to your way of playing.

3. The huge ammount of maps:
I have looked at some of the new RTS games, and one thing that turns me off is the map selection. They will have about 10-20 maps, usually with 1 map being an 8 player (if they even have 8 players allowed) this game however has over 100 maps! With both even maps for competitive matches or more unfair maps for free for alls, 2v2v2's 2v2v2v2's etc.

4. The game play is both fun to watch, and very competitive (suits any style of play)
Even after 4+ years of playing this game, I still learn new things, tactics, this game is very balanced, and there is no issue of players spamming mass of units to win.

If you do get this game and enjoy it, I strongly reccomend you download the supermod 'Ultimate Apocalypse mod' The latest version is 'The Hunt Begins'

reviewText:
There are a few issues that need to be highlighted regarding Soulstorm before I begin listing the positive aspects of this game. First off, the game has a lot of issues with loading, particularly with the campaign. Though I'll readily admit that my computer isn't a good one, the general concensus is that no game should keep you waiting as long as the Soulstorm Campaign does, so have a book or handheld system by your side if you intend to play the campaign. Secondly, as I'm sure a good chunk of you know, most of the voice acting for the Campaign mode is absolutely terrible, but this isn't a major issue as much as it is a gripe (most of the issues regarding the game come from the campaign).

Now, on to the postives.

This expansion adds two new factions to play as, the Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar, both of which are welcome additions to the game. Both bring new strategies to the table, as well as giving you a better look at the 40k universe (I say this because Dawn of War is most people's gateway to Warhammer 40,000). The gameplay is still solid (though of course balance is still a major issue), because few expansion packs can really mess up gameplay.

And last but not least, the real reason you should purchase this game: The mods.

There are dozens of amazing mods for Soulstorm, from ambitious gameplay overhauls like Titanium Wars and Ultimate Apocalypse, to new factions (complete with voice acting) like the Armageddon Steel Legion and Tyranids. If you're not sure about getting Soulstorm, do it for the mods.

reviewText:
Soulstorm is the final and in my opinion, best expansion for the critically acclaimed Dawn Of War I franchise that got unfortunately hounded by reviewers at launch, but was greatly enhanced by both official patches and mods that made this game one of the most famous and game-changing RTS's out there.

+ Standalone expansion that adds the fanatical sisters of battle, with a a wide array of artillery and faith based attacks, and the sadistic, twisted dark eldar, who are nothing like the original Eldar faction and are the epitome of the term glass cannon with the highest damage in the game, but also the worst health I've ever seen.

+ Balanced older factions making it a better experience for all

+ Those that own Soulstorm do not need any other part of DOW I to play with others who own the franchise (assuming they too own atleast Soulstorm) but you are restricted from the factions added in other expansions giving you access to only 2 of the 9

+ The meta-campaign returns giving you the ability to fight in the 9-way war for Kaurava.

+ Airforce based units are added making fighter jets available to all (except the Necron, but they get a spell that hijacks vehicles permenantly now) adding a new level of diversity to the combat as they dont follow the same movement restrictions as ground troops.

+The game can be further enhanced with the legendary Ultimate Apocalypse mod adding new balance changes, better graphics, units, and redoes every faction from the ground up making them as the Codex Astartes (basically lore for the universe for the  heretics  those unfamiliar with the lore reading this ) states making it one of the greatest mods for any game ever. That is a fact, opinions do not matter in the 40th millenia.

- The ai is still kinda wonky on lower difficulties and will not always utilize their best features on higher ones. For example, the Eldar, who are meant to be a teleportation based army with weak hit-and-run style units, will instead opt for buildig multiple unupgraded guardian (rifleman) squads and rush you by the two minute mark. This works well if you didnt build a turret which mows them down violently, but it still doesn't fit with how that faction was meant to work. This can be fixed with mods however.

-Due to age, and a community divided over mods, finding people to play with isn't always easy. If you have friends into RTS games however, this game is a god(emperor)send.

-The new aerial units take a lot of damage from even basic infantry making them not very viable in many instances. So if your looking for some high end combined arms assault, all your gonna get is some quality infantry and armored vehicles fighting as dead pilots drop down.

-The controversial commander units are back, though not as dangerous as they are in the second game as they are still very much killable by even the weaker units. In my opinion, they aren't too much of an issue and as a concept add to the game, though balance is a tad bit skewed as some armies get their primary and best commanders at the beginning like the Space/Chaos marines and dark eldar when others have to wait for a base upgrade or other enhancement. I feel that these guys have a bit too much early game infantry harassment but by the end is no issue.

-A full-fleged story based campaign is still absent like in Dark Crusade but the new campaign format included in the two allows you to play as your favorite faction instead of either the Space marines in the base game, or 1-2 missions for each in the Winter Assault.

In conclusion, the game still holds up and is still fantastic to play in both standard and the Ultimate Apocalypse mod. Balance still isn't perfect, but the more you play you should be able to master and hold up as any faction making it one of the most biggest and greatest RTS games out there.

As someone who is no stranger to the RTS genre, I'll admit, this one threw me for a loop at first!

The most interesting thing here is the campaign.  Typically, your average RTS is either a survival game where you build up forces to withstand assault or it's a level-by-level progression, where you complete sequential missions.  This was the first time I actually felt like I was playing both at once.  The campaign mode of this game is odd, but in a good way; it's a refreshing way to bridge the two different styles of RTS into a unique gameplay system.

Another interesting mechanic is the different races in the game.  Usually, different races will have a general build order that all follow the same way, or there are a few radically different races.  With this game, each race has a unique build style to explore!  The Imperial Guard have garrisonable buildings, the Eldar can Teleport, the Battle Sisters have Holy Relics... it's like each race is it's own unique game!

(P.S.: If you're a bigtime RTS player like I am, and you're just now getting into this game, then I recommend starting as the Tau when you first play this game; their build order is more familiar to folks coming from a Starcraft or CiV background.)

Enjoy playing a game that stands tall and proud even now. Enjoy playing a game that has virtually no balance problems. Enjoy playing a game with 9 different races that somehow all play the same, something that Starcraft 2 Heart of The Swarm currently is beginning to fail at.

Enjoy playing a game where each race has a super weapon that is literally a giant unit from a giant tank, to a large, fat pyramid-ish cube with a giant laser beam, or even a big pig...thing with lasers on it's head, bigger than the swimming pool you went to last month.

Trust me... these Super Weapons put Command and Conquer's Super Weapons at the kiddie table, they make them look like pea shooters almost. Oh... what's that? One is an energy field that makes all tanks and vehicles invulnerable for a short time? One of them is an ion blast fired from a sattelite in space or something? One of them is a nuke?

Only the Nuke super weapon stands up to any of these.

The game works off of unlimited resources known as Requisition and Power. Power, you make generators to make, and Requisition is gained from taking and holding points throughout a map. Both can be upgraded in a different way to produce more resources faster.

Anyonewho is a fan of strategy games who has NOT played this one is just simply missing out.

This game is the closest anyone will ever get to a seemingly perfect game in it's own rights, and to add to it, it's got wonderful voiceacting, awesome soundtracks and rather impressive visuals for it's time, all of which stands just aswell today.

Hardcore RTS fans can agree that if you are a HUGE fan of the Real-Time Strategy Game, you owe it to yourself to try this.

The game has 3 expansions, the first one adds The Imperial Gaurd, the second adds the Tau and Necrons, and the thirds adds the Sisters of Battle and the Dark Eldar.

All 3 add onto the game and simply make it one of the best if not the best RTS in existence so far.

Also only Soulstorm has much of an actual multiplayer, because people only play it, so if multiplayer is what you're looking for... well try out the skirmish mode, and if you like this, get the 3 expansions and join us in the crusade to kill eachother!

This game is easily an 8/10, it's simply gaming bliss.

reviewText:
Before reading the fact I recommend the game, keep in mind that the game is better with mods which is what really makes it worth buying and replaying. Overall hours played if I count the time before I finally decided to re-purchase it via Steam is about 1.5k hours as this was the most played strategy game in my collection back in the day.

Vanilla Review:

Dawn of War Soulstorm has many, many unfinished abilities and units which take away from the overall effect of multiplayer and campaign abilities. While in itself it is still a good title and a replayable campaign for AI grinding is still fun, if Relic/THQ had actually finished their project, it would of been a lot better.

The Campaign is basically a repeat of Dark Crusade but you got Tau and Sisters of Battle now which isn't really that much. Overall balancing is okay but there is a lot left to be desired such as knockback spam being hard to counter or defend against and special weapons troopers always being the first to die even if they're in the back of the squad being attacked.

The vanilla version also does a very poor job at vehicle implementation particularly with aircraft as they're glorified glass cannons in some cases (Orks) and useless in almsot all accords (Imperial Guard).  Limiting special units in most cases where in Dark Crusade you could have more is a double edged sword and the limits should of been raised. Having the ability to only create one elite troop unit compared to three back in Dark Crusade is a major debuff in my opinion and overall takes away from the fighting experience as most of them are very weak to begin with.

The developers have also neglected balancing between every race. Races such as the Orks and Tau are extremely powerful against most other factions and in some cases you can't even win if it's against a competent player or the AI on the highest difficulty such as Orks vs Imperial Guard....you can't even win in a balanced fight particularly if it's 3v3 or 4v4 due to the Invulnerability spam on Ork units. Now if you do Orks vs Space Marines or even Eldar, it's a lot easier because the races aren't glass cannons. Imperial Guard it seems has been mostly balanced from a 1v1 stand point and team fight with non-Imperial Guard races which is a shame because they should be able to do well in team fights with other Guard players but in almost every instance, that is not the case. Sisters of Battle are extremely strong in all stages of the game and honestly minus the fact they're basically infantry only, can beat almost every faction in a 1v2 instance. Tau are glorified glass cannons and with the length of their tech tree, most games end before you can even begin to put the hurt on the enemy in a 1v1. Their entire tech tree is based off long team fights where they really shine and often end up losing in early game fights on small maps due to their higher maintenance costs and the lack of defenses. Eldar/Dark Eldar and SM/CSM have changed very little and are good at all stages, no reall balancing needed. reviewText:
Soulstorm is the latest and most-played expansion pack to Dawn of War. It offers the most balance, though it's still one of the less balanced RTS games, and it has the most races.

The Warhammer 40K really comes to live in this game, with memorable quotes from units and mouth-watering visuals as lasers and rockets fly. Units have special kill animations during battles in melee, making them visually impressive whether you're zoomed out or zoomed in. Each of the many factions plays very differently, from the Orks and their unit-swarming powers to the Necrons and their utterly free, but slow, units.

There's a replayable campaign in Soulstorm, similar to the one offered in Dark Crusade, but most players will find their playtime in skirmishes and online. I highly reccomend playing with friends if you aren't competitive. Also of note, Soulstorm has a very impressive free mod named Codex that adds -a ton- of variety and also has options to increase the population limits on battles, allowing giant wars worthy of the Warhammer name. This mod is well worth looking into once you're done with the vanilla game.

reviewText:
Soulstorm is pretty much a carbon copy of Dark Crusade. It's a standalone expansion to Dawn of War that adds two new races and using the new non-linear Grand Strategy style campaign map that THQ have grown so fond of.

Like in Dark Crusade there is really no learning curve for new players. You are thrown directly into the fray with no introduction to the gameplay, units or technologies and just have to wing it as best you can. Also like in Dark Crusade you can only use the new races in multi-player unless you already own the previous Dawn of War games which is really a bummer for anyone that buys this with the intention to play with friends.

The single-player is the continued development of Dark Crusade and the campaign works much the same way. The introduction of two new factions have made the map a bit bigger and this doesn't help as it only adds more grind. Playing through the single-player is essentially a progression of skirmish maps and it becomes boring, very fast. The stronghold maps are quite entertaining but they are the only fun thing in the campaign so you'll often find yourself dreading going into battle against yet another pointless incursion into your territory.

The new factions introduced in Soulstorm aren't quite as interesting as the ones introduced in Dark Crusade either. Firstly you have the Sisters of Battle which are essentially the super fanatical military arm of the Ordo Hereticus" in the Empire of Man. Essentially they are the people you send when it's time to massacre your own people in great numbers. They have no remorse and will willing sacrifice anyone in the name of the Emperor. In game they play much like the Space Marines
date: in fact they are eerily similar in terms of unit composition to the regular Space Marines

only with a somewhat disturbing tendency towards pyromania.

The second new faction are the Dark Eldar which are what the Chaos Space Marines to the Eldar. Unfortunately they are not nearly as cool or as interesting. They feel like some Eldar went and smoked some Chaos but forgot to inhale. In terms of gameplay they are little more interesting than the Sisters of Battle with their fast moving units but they don't really add too much to the formula.

Both factions read really well in the WH40K universe but their implementation in the Dawn of War franchise feels really poor. They just lose so much of their personality when they don't have any proper campaigns

reviewText:
By far the best real-time strategy game I've ever played.  While the Soulstorm expansion is somewhat forgettable, it stacks onto the other expansions that really crafted DoW into a one-of-a-kind RTS experience, especially Dark Crusade.

While other RTS games might have a really engrossing storyline or RPG mechanics, no other RTS I've played matches DoW on gameplay.
Squad leader attachment, weapon upgrades, reinforcement, the whole capture-point mechanic... this game does it all and pulls it off well.

The skirmish mode is a blast to co-op or test yourself solo against the computer.
The game is certainly a game of skill and you will find great satisfaction in picking your favorite, of the staggering quantity of fairly unique races, and mastering it.
I recommend the DOW AI MOD if you want to play against the CPU for fun.
Purge The Heretics!

Digestable Scifi Fantasy Brutallity.
Even if you haven't heard of the Warhammer franchise, but dig even the concept of RTS and dozens of screaming religous space loonatics tearing eachother into bloody pieces, you will love this.
This game is one of the least demanding RTS in terms of player competency so newcomers to the genre will feel immediately welcome.
Also, the resource model is point-capture, meaning that even if you try to build up the ultimate army before deciding it's time to kill the other guy, you still have to issue squads (not single units) out in the open to capture and protect resource points to even start making that army. Like WarCraft 3's hero leveling system, this leaves each match no room for snorefest turtling and it's sweet sweet killing all the time, every time.
But be warned, even though the industry is seriously lacking in game demos, do not try this game's demo. You'll only get to try the wimpiest race in the game in 2 lousy singleplayer levels. For the uninitiated, this would misrepresent the game as it has motherloving 9 RACES to play in Total-War-style singleplayer and 2 for multiplayer (buy the base game and/or the other expansions to play their respective races in multiplayer) - one of which is the goth kid Dark Eldar and the other (my personal favorite), the screaming roid rage space nuns of Humanity itself: The Sisters of Battle.

Having played all of the other Dawn of War games, this one certainly seems to be the weakest of the series.  Don't get me wrong, it's still a load of fun, but when compared to the other installments in the series, this one feels a bit phoned in.

If you've ever played Dark Crusade, it's very much like that.  But, in case you haven't, in Soulstorm you choose one of nine factions to lead to victory over the Kaurava system.  The system is divided into territories spanned across 4 planets and 3 moons.  Each faction starts controlling a certain number of territories, whereas the player starts with only a single territory.  Each faction must then battle it out for control of each territory in the system.  You defeat other factions by conquering their primary territory, known as their stronghold.

In Dark Crusade the campaign played out in much the same fashion, but over a single planet rather than a system.  Furthermore, the backstory for the planet and each of the individual territories felt much more fleshed out in Dark Crusade.  The reasoning for the presence of each faction was better explained and the entire game just seemd to have more personality.

Aside from this, Soulstorm is really just more of the same.  And that's great if you're a Dawn of War fan.  It's great to finally see the Adepta Sororitas (Sisters of Battle) added to the game and the gameplay works just as well as it ever has.

Ultimately, I would recommend this game but only if you enjoyed the other Dawn of War installments.  If this is your first introduction to the Dawn of War Series, I would strongly recommend playing the other games first.

This is a real-time strategy game. Not a big game of rock-paper-scissors (ala C&C, which I do love as well), or who-can-make-the-most-the-fastest (ala Starcraft, less love but more hours in my younger days).
The campaigns are pretty good. I especially enjoyed Winter Assualt, despite it being very short. Call me a sucker for hopeless military stories. Soulstorm is better, though. It plays like a board game, taking over the planet, battling other factions. You win a battle, you take some land and get bonuses later. You lose, you wait until the next turn and plan your next move. Then move in and play what I think (because this is a review) is the best RTS experience since...well, nothing else I've played really matches it.
Despite the huge number of different armies availible with all expansions, everything is pretty well balanced. Everything caters to different players. How do a bunch of Orks beat a bunch of Space Marines, or a group of Tau beat some Eldar? You have to figure it out. The same thing doesn't work against everyone. This is a real-time strategy game. Not a big game of rock-paper-scissors (ala C&C, which I do love as well), or who-can-make-the-most-the-fastest (ala Starcraft, less love but more hours in my younger days).
The campaigns are pretty good. I especially enjoyed Winter Assualt, despite it being very short. Call me a sucker for hopeless military stories. Soulstorm is better, though. It plays like a board game, taking over the planet, battling other factions. You win a battle, you take some land and get bonuses later. You lose, you wait until the next turn and plan your next move. Then move in and play what I think (because this is a review) is the best RTS experience since...well, nothing else I've played really matches it.
Despite the huge number of different armies availible with all expansions, everything is pretty well balanced. Everything caters to different players. How do a bunch of Orks beat a bunch of Space Marines, or a group of Tau beat some Eldar? You have to figure it out. The same thing doesn't work against everyone. And when you have an eight-player free-for-all, what do you do? Endless options, endless replayability.

It's the 41st Milenium and let's hope war indeed never changes.

Even if you haven't heard of the Warhammer franchise, but dig even the concept of RTS and dozens of screaming religous space loonatics tearing eachother into bloody pieces, you will love this.
This game is one of the least demanding RTS in terms of player competency so newcomers to the genre will feel immediately welcome.
Also, the resource model is point-capture, meaning that even if you try to build up the ultimate army before deciding it's time to kill the other guy, you still have to issue squads (not single units) out in the open to capture and protect resource points to even start making that army. Like WarCraft 3's hero leveling system, this leaves each match no room for snorefest turtling and it's sweet sweet killing all the time, every time.
But be warned, even though the industry is seriously lacking in game demos, do not try this game's demo. You'll only get to try the wimpiest race in the game in 2 lousy singleplayer levels. For the uninitiated, this would misrepresent the game as it has motherloving 9 RACES to play in Total-War-style singleplayer and 2 for multiplayer (buy the base game and/or the other expansions to play their respective races in multiplayer) - one of which is the goth kid Dark Eldar and the other (my personal favorite), the screaming roid rage space nuns of Humanity itself: The Sisters of Battle.
Note: Game crashes if you alt-tab. Extremely embarrassing bug to leave untouched for however many years that this came out.
With out a doubt the  Greatest Game of all Time,\n\nBuy this game
